repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Provincial and Peri-Urban Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Provincial and
            Peri-Urban Water Supply and Sanitation Project for Cambodia
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was substantial, the Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: as a local Cambodian Non-Governmental
            Organization (NGO), Center for Development (CfD) which
            worked for other donors as well was effective in empowering
            communities to become actors in local development projects.
            CfD's approach of awareness-raising, social
            mobilization and increasing access to improved facilities
            can be considered a model for replication, especially for
            projects where demand needs to be triggered at the
            grassroots level. At the same time, it should be recognized
            that an NGO's weak capacity and lack of familiarity
            with Bank procedures are challenges for an NGO to implement
            Bank-financed projects, and mitigation measures should be
            included. As social mobilization agents, Clean Water Groups
            (CWGs) provided clear benefits to their communities,
            including the Private Water Operators (PWOs), with little or
            no reward in return. Rather than relying solely on official
            local leaders at the village and commune levels, the CWG
            served as an effective, valued-added community
            representative for the success of local development
            activities. It is important to conduct a water consumption
            survey during project preparation stage in order to get a
            clear estimate of the water consumption rate. As water
            consumption has deep financial implications, conducting such
            a survey could avoid the possibility of over estimating or
            underestimating consumption, thereby minimizing any
            potential financial loss for the utility company. Given the
            innovative private sector participation component for
            Cambodia, the project should have included a specific
            Technical Assistance (TA) component to train prospective
            bidders on Bank procurement procedures, and on how to
            prepare responsive technical and financial bids, instead of
            leaving this task to the Mekong Private Sector Development
            Facility, which was not formally a part of the project. Such
            training may have stimulated private sector response even more.

repnme.cdata!:
Cambodia - Provincial and Peri-Urban Water
            and Sanitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Provincial and
            Peri-Urban Water and Sanitation Project is to assist the
            Kingdom of Cambodia to move forward in fulfilling the
            Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) in water supply and
            sanitation by 2015. The restructuring will: (a) close the
            provincial water supply component, and transfer the
            remaining available funds to support: (i) the scaling-up of
            the sanitation component (part A, being implemented by the
            non-governmental organization (NGO) 'Center for
            Development' (CfD); and (ii) additional investments to
            expand water supply in the Peri-urban water supply component
            (part B, implemented by the Phnom Penh Water Supply
            Authority (PPWSA), the PPWSA component); and (b) adjust the
            key performance indicators. This project paper also proposes
            to extend, for the second time, the credit closing date,
            from the current closing date of June 30, 2010 to June 30,
            2011, for a total extension of three years.
